sections.heading: What Are Filler Words?
sections.content:
Filler words (つなぎ言葉 tsunagi kotoba or 間投詞 kantoushi) are sounds and words used to fill pauses while thinking, hesitating, or transitioning between thoughts. Every language has them - Japanese is no exception.

Why learn fillers?

Sound more natural and native-like Give yourself time to think while speaking Make conversation flow smoothly Show you're listening and engaged Essential for natural speech patterns

English equivalents: "um," "uh," "well," "like," "you know"

children.heading: あのー (ano-) / あの (ano) - Um... / Well...
children.content:
The most common hesitation word, used when thinking or starting a difficult topic.

Uses:

Thinking of what to say Politely starting a conversation Getting someone's attention Introducing a delicate topic

あのー、質問があるんですが。 Ano-, shitsumon ga aru n desu ga. "Um, I have a question..." あの、すみません。 Ano, sumimasen. "Excuse me..." [Getting attention] あのー、ちょっといいですか？ Ano-, chotto ii desu ka? "Um, do you have a moment?"

Pronunciation note: Often elongated (ano-) when thinking.

children.heading: えーと (e-to) / ええと (eeto) - Let me see... / Umm...
children.content:
Used when trying to remember something or thinking.

えーと、何だっけ？ E-to, nan datta kke? "Let me see, what was it again?" ええと、明日は... Eeto, ashita wa... "Um, tomorrow is..." えーと、えーと... E-to, e-to... "Umm, umm..." [Thinking hard]

Similar to: English "let's see..." or "umm..."

children.heading: えー (e-) - Uh... / Umm...
children.content:
Simple hesitation sound, like English "uh."

えー、それは... E-, sore wa... "Uh, that's..." えー、ちょっと待って。 E-, chotto matte. "Uh, wait a moment."

children.heading: なんか (nanka) - Like... / Kind of... / Somehow
children.content:
Very common filler, similar to English "like."

Uses:

Vague expression Softening statements Searching for words Casual speech

なんか、変な感じ。 Nanka, hen na kanji. "Like, it feels weird." なんか疲れた。 Nanka tsukareta. "I'm kind of tired." なんかさー Nanka sa- "Like, you know..."

Note: Can be overused, especially by young people.

children.heading: その (sono) - That... / Um...
children.content:
Used as a filler while thinking of what to say next.

その、聞きたいことがあって... Sono, kikitai koto ga atte... "Um, there's something I want to ask..." その、実は... Sono, jitsu wa... "Well, actually..."

children.heading: まあ (maa) - Well... / So-so / I guess
children.content:
Multi-purpose filler for transitions or moderate opinions.

Uses:

Softening statements "Well, I suppose..." "More or less" Transitioning topics

まあ、そうだね。 Maa, sou da ne. "Well, I guess so." まあまあです。 Maa maa desu. "It's so-so." / "Not bad." まあ、いいか。 Maa, ii ka. "Well, I guess it's okay." まあまあ Maa maa "Now, now..." [Calming someone]

children.heading: で (de) / でさ (de sa) - And / So
children.content:
Casual connector, continuing a story.

で、どうしたの？ De, doushita no? "And then what happened?" / "So?" でさ、その後ね... De sa, sono ato ne... "And like, after that..."

children.heading: だから (dakara) - So / That's why
children.content:
Connects to previous statement, shows consequence.

だから、言ったでしょ。 Dakara, itta desho. "That's why I told you." だからさー Dakara sa- "So like..." / "That's why..."

children.heading: というか (to iu ka) - Or rather... / I mean...
children.content:
Correcting or clarifying your statement.

難しいというか、面倒くさい。 Muzukashii to iu ka, mendokusai. "It's difficult, or rather, it's a pain." 嬉しいというか、びっくりした。 Ureshii to iu ka, bikkuri shita. "I'm happy, or I mean, I'm surprised."

children.heading: なんていうか (nan te iu ka) - How should I say... / What's the word...
children.content:
Searching for the right word or expression.

なんていうか、変な感じ。 Nan te iu ka, hen na kanji. "How should I say, it feels weird." なんていうかな... Nan te iu ka na... "How can I put it..."

children.heading: そうですね (sou desu ne) - Let me think... / That's right...
children.content:
Can mean agreement OR be a filler while thinking.

そうですね... [elongated] Sou desu ne... "Let me think..." [Filler] そうですね。[short] Sou desu ne. "That's right." [Agreement]

Key: Length determines meaning - longer = thinking, shorter = agreeing.

children.heading: なるほど (naruhodo) - I see / That makes sense
children.content:
Showing understanding, acknowledging information.

なるほど、そういうことか。 Naruhodo, sou iu koto ka. "I see, so that's how it is." なるほどね。 Naruhodo ne. "I see." / "That makes sense."

children.heading: へー (he-) - Oh! / Really?
children.content:
Showing mild surprise or interest.

へー、そうなんだ。 He-, sou nan da. "Oh, really?" / "Huh, is that so?" へー！知らなかった。 He-! Shiranakatta. "Oh! I didn't know that."

children.heading: ふーん (fu-n) - Hmm / Oh
children.content:
Neutral acknowledgment, sometimes dismissive.

ふーん、そう。 Fu-n, sou. "Hmm, okay." [Can sound uninterested] ふーん... Fu-n... "Hmm..." [Thinking or skeptical]

Warning: Can sound dismissive or uninterested if not careful.

children.heading: はー (ha-) - Wow / Oh my
children.content:
Expressing impression or exhaling.

はー、疲れた。 Ha-, tsukareta. "Whew, I'm tired." はー、すごいね。 Ha-, sugoi ne. "Wow, that's amazing."

children.heading: ちょっと (chotto) - A bit / Wait / Um
children.content:
Softens statements or asks for thinking time.

ちょっと待って。 Chotto matte. "Wait a moment." / "Hold on." ちょっと分からない。 Chotto wakaranai. "I don't really understand." ちょっと...それは... Chotto... sore wa... "Um... that's..." [Uncomfortable/declining]

Note: Elongating "ちょっと..." often implies polite refusal.

children.heading: 何て言うか (nan te iu ka) - What do you call it / How do I say
children.content:
Buying time to find the right word.

何て言うか、その、あれ。 Nan te iu ka, sono, are. "What's it called, um, that thing."

children.heading: あれ (are) - That thing / What's-it-called
children.content:
Placeholder for forgotten words.

あれ、何だっけ？ Are, nan datta kke? "That thing, what was it?" あれを取って。 Are wo totte. "Pass me that thing." [When you forgot the name]

children.heading: ね (ne) - Right? / You know?
children.content:
Keeps conversation going, checks for understanding.

今日は寒いですね。 Kyou wa samui desu ne. "It's cold today, isn't it?" で、その後ね、 De, sono ato ne, "And then, you know,"

children.heading: さ (sa) - You know / Like
children.content:
Casual filler, more masculine.

だからさ、 Dakara sa, "So like," それでさ、 Sorede sa, "And then, you know," 行こうよ、ね？ Ikou yo, ne? "Let's go, okay?"

children.heading: ほら (hora) - Look / See / You know
children.content:
Drawing attention to something or reminding.

ほら、言ったでしょ。 Hora, itta desho. "See, I told you." ほら、あそこ！ Hora, asoko! "Look, over there!" ほら、あの人... Hora, ano hito... "You know, that person..." [Trying to remember]

children.heading: あのさ (ano sa) - Hey / So / Um
children.content:
Casual, often used in Tokyo area.

あのさ、ちょっといい？ Ano sa, chotto ii? "Hey, got a minute?"

children.heading: なんや (nanya) - Kansai Dialect
children.content:
Kansai version of なんか.

なんや知らんけど Nanya shiran kedo "I don't know why but..." [Kansai]

children.heading: さー (sa-) / さあ (saa) - Well... / Let's see...
children.content:
Pondering or uncertainty.

さあ、どうだろう。 Saa, dou darou. "Well, I wonder..." さあね。 Saa ne. "Well, who knows?" / "Beats me."

children.heading: Polite Context
children.content: あのー、すみませんが... (Ano-, sumimasen ga...) えーと、少々お待ちください。(E-to, shoushou omachi kudasai.) そうですね... (Sou desu ne...)

children.heading: Casual Context
children.content: あのさ、 (Ano sa,) えーと、ちょっと待って。(E-to, chotto matte.) そうだね... (Sou da ne...)

children.heading: Buying Time
children.content:
えーと、そうですね、なんていうか... E-to, sou desu ne, nan te iu ka... "Um, let me see, how should I put it..."

Stack fillers naturally when you really need time to think.

children.heading: Softening Difficult Topics
children.content: あのー、その、ちょっと聞きにくいんですけど... Ano-, sono, chotto kikinukui n desu kedo... "Um, well, this is a bit hard to ask but..."

children.heading: Showing Engagement
children.content:
へー、なるほど、そうなんですね。 He-, naruhodo, sou nan desu ne. "Oh, I see, is that so."

Proper filler use shows you're listening actively.

sections.heading: Common Filler Combinations
sections.content: あのー、えーと... (Ano-, e-to...) - "Um, let's see..." なんか、その... (Nanka, sono...) - "Like, um..." まあ、そうですね... (Maa, sou desu ne...) - "Well, I suppose..." というか、なんていうか... (To iu ka, nan te iu ka...) - "Or rather, how should I say..."

sections.heading: Filler Frequency
sections.content:
Natural use: 1-3 fillers per minute in casual conversation Too few: Sounds rehearsed or unnatural Too many: Sounds uncertain or unprepared

Balance is key - use fillers naturally without overdoing it.

children.heading: Mistake 1: Overusing なんか
children.content:
❌ なんか、今日はなんか、なんか疲れた。 ✓ なんか、今日は疲れた。

One or two fillers per sentence is enough.

children.heading: Mistake 2: Wrong Context Fillers
children.content:
❌ In business presentation: えーと、なんかさー ✓ In business: あのー、そうですね

Match filler formality to context.

children.heading: Mistake 3: No Fillers at All
children.content:
❌ Sounds robotic: 私は学生です。東京に住んでいます。日本語を勉強しています。 ✓ More natural: えーと、私は学生で、東京に住んでて、まあ、日本語を勉強してます。

Some fillers make you sound more natural.

children.heading: Mistake 4: English Fillers in Japanese
children.content:
❌ Um... like... you know... ✓ あのー... なんか... ですね...

Use Japanese fillers when speaking Japanese.

sections.heading: Summary
sections.content:
Essential Fillers to Master:

あのー (ano-) - Um, well (most versatile) えーと (e-to) - Let me see, umm なんか (nanka) - Like, kind of まあ (maa) - Well, I guess そうですね (sou desu ne) - Let me think なるほど (naruhodo) - I see ちょっと (chotto) - A bit, wait

Key Points:

Fillers are essential for natural speech Give you time to think while maintaining flow Show engagement and active listening Must match formality level of conversation Don't overuse - 1-3 per thought is natural Practice listening to native speakers' filler patterns
